content.description: Short and stout gear route.  Start behind a big, gnarly, half-dead madrone tree.  Follow the steep crack system slightly right, then back left over a small bulge.  Small hands crux.
content.location: Crack system in the middle of the crag, behind the big madrone.

content.description: Awkward start to juggy middle section. Head left before the last bolt for the slightly harder/better finish. Not the best route, but one of the only warm-ups at the Tropics/Three Amigos.  Skies were super smoky from forest fires during the FA, hence the name.
content.location: Far right side of Tropics Wall.

content.description: 5.10- jugs for a couple bolts, then head into a funky flare.  Crux passing the last bolt and getting to the anchors.  Climbs way better than it looks.  Named for the deceptive steepness of the route, and because one of the FA party was massively hungover.
content.location: Farthest left route on the Tropics Wall.

content.description:
Grow a Pear is an exciting line up the outside of the obvious chimney in the center of the rock. From a distance, it may not look like much, but when you get up to it, the route is steep, well featured, and very safe. Clipping the 5th bolt will test the rope management skills of new leaders. It is a great beginner lead or warm up for the other harder climbs around. Aside from directing falls in a safe direction, the draws keep the rope completely off the rock.

Bolt finding beta:

Near the bush after the second bolt, reach up and right to clip the third bolt above the first shelf. Move up and left left into the chimney and reach up and right to clip the fourth bolt. The crux is moving to the fifth bolt on the left wall, use wide chimney or stemming technique. The sixth bolt is on the right side of the crack higher up, and anchors back again on the left.
content.protection: 6 bolts and 2 bolt anchor. Rap off chains

content.description:
Forbidden Fruit is marked by a very impressive 45-degree overhanging prow top out.

Climb the first four bolts of Grow A Pear and instead of following the chimney, start stemming up and out until you can reach a good enough hold to pull into the overhang. Most people donâ€™t stem high enough. Trust the jug and let your feet cut wildly. Two more bolts and steep jugs (with a few long reaches) land you on a giant clipping jug above the chains.

It would be possible to exit the roof out left, but that would actually not be any easier; it is very dirty, mungy, and without any protection or anchors. So enjoy the overhang and one of the steepest routes around here.
content.location: Climb the first four bolts of Grow A Pear and head right to the overhanging prow.

content.description: Overhanging jugs for the first 3 bolts.  Crux at the 4th bolt, making a long move past a small sidepull to a meathook sloper.  Vertical edges and funky horns to the anchors.  Great route.
content.location: To the right of the large madrone tree.

content.description:
Climb right of the bolt line to the third bolt with a fun rose-move traverse left to some good crimps. Rest up on a good jug below the 4th bolt, then aim for a juggy pinch to clip the last bolt. The crux comes as you manage a tecnhical foot sequence that allows a difficult lobster-claw right hand pinch and left hand deadpoint to a sidepull. Once you bump to the second sidepull, the route should be in the bag!

The crux is short, and the lead up is pretty mellow, but it is easy to pitch off right when you think you've got it. I am considering moving the anchors up 2-3' if the rock will take it.
